landing.h2: Welcome to the iSCAPE Citizen Kit!
landing.h4: Let’s get you set up with a Smart Citizen Kit, and sensing in no time!

smart_citizen.h2: Smart Citizen is a movement for civic participation in a modern world
smart_citizen.h4: Smart Citizen creates open tools for citizens to be better informed about the world around them

smart_citizen_brief.h4: This sensor is a Smart Citizen Kit for environmental sensing. It measures sound, air quality, humidity, and lots of other things

smart_citizen_brief2.h4: The kit sends all the measurements to the Smart Citizen website. It's open and free for all to see, question and play with...

whats_in_the_box.h4: There's a few pieces we need to set up the Kit, let's check we have them all

kitbuild1.text: You should have the Kit, a micro SD adapter, a USB cable and charger, and a rubber band

kitbuild2.text: Connect the battery to the hardware board

kitbuild3.h2: Remember, you'll need to charge it periodically
kitbuild3.text: Plug the USB and charge your device like your phone

kitbuild4.h2: And finally, ensure the LED is red
kitbuild4.text: Push the button on the Kit multiple times, until the LED is red

kitenclosure_start.h4: We will show you how to make a simple enclosure

kitenclosure1.text: Use scissors to cut an empty plastic bottle into two parts, about 12 cm from the top

kitenclosure2.text: Secondly, use the rubber band to fix it using the bottle cap

kitenclosure3.text: Third, place the Kit inside and use the rubber band to hold it in place

kitenclosure4.text: You now have a simple enclosure to use your Kit outdoors for short measurement periods!

sdcard_inplace.text: Ensure your Kit has a micro SD card inserted to record the data

case1.h2: Next, we'll place everything inside the casing
case1.text: Make sure you position it with the battery cable towards the bottom of the casing

case2.h2: .... and to finish, seal the cover
case2.text: Place the transparent plastic on the front of the case and fix it in place with the two white plugs

choose_connection.h2: How do you want to use your kit?
choose_connection.part1_desc: In network mode, the sensor can publish data to smartcitizen.me over your Wi-Fi every minute. The kit supports Wi-Fi WEP, WPA/WPA2 and open networks, which are common networks in domestic environments and small businesses. However, it does not support WPA/WPA2 enterprise networks such as EDUROAM or networks with captive portals such as the ones in airports and hotels
choose_connection.part2_desc: If you do not have an internet connection you can use the SD mode. In this case the device will record the data on the micro SD card. Later, we can read the card using a card reader. The data can be visualized in a spreadsheet but also published on the smartcitizen.me platform using the UPLOAD CSV option.

wifi_enter.h2: What network are we connecting it to?
wifi_enter.h4: We have to type it in manually...
wifi_enter.input1_error: A name is required to connect to a network

handshake.h4: Hold your kit up and press it on the screen over the box below and press 'connect'. Make sure the blue side of the kit is facing you

wifi_check.h4: It seems there is a problem. Check your Kit light is red and your Wi-Fi name and password are correct
wifi_check.input1_error: A name is required to connect to a network

accesspoint_1.h2: On your mobile device, go to your Wi-Fi settings and connect to the Wi-Fi called:
accesspoint_1.h3_2: of the Kit, located in the
accesspoint_1.h4: If you do not see it, make sure your kit is powered on with a red LED. If you see many, select the one ending with the characters printed in your Kit

accesspoint_2.h2: You should see this window on your mobile device
accesspoint_2.h3_1: If that did not happen, open the browser on your device and go to www.sck.me
accesspoint_2.h4: If it does not work, make sure you are connected to the Wi-Fi

ap_token.h2: Press start and then type your device key
ap_token.h4: When asked for your token enter the code above

ap_wifi.h2: Now select your Wi-Fi from the list, and enter the password.
ap_wifi.h4: If the submitted wifi and password are correct you will be redirected shortly

ap_final.h4: If the submitted wifi and password are correct your Kit LED will turn blue and you'll be redirected shortly

ap_issues.h4: Ensure the light on you Kit is red before trying to connect, check you entered your WiFi password correctly and ensure you are close enough to your router

offline_pre.h1: No Wi-Fi? No problem, use an SD Card
offline_pre.h4: You will need a phone and a micro SD card. You can upload the data to the platform later using the CSV upload option in the platform Kits profile

kitbuild_sd.text: Ensure your Kit has a micro SD card inserted to record the data

offline_1.h2: On your mobile device, go to your Wi-Fi settings and connect to the Wi-Fi called:
offline_1.h3_2: of the Kit, located in the
offline_1.h4: If you do not see it, make sure your Kit is turned on with a red LED.  If you see many Wi-Fi networks, select the one ending with the characters printed in your Kit

offline_2.h2: You should see this window on your mobile device
offline_2.h3_1: Click on the 'SD Card mode' link
offline_2.h4: If it does not work, make sure you are connected to the right Wi-Fi

offline_3.h3_1: The Kit LED should be fading in pink
offline_3.h4: If the LED is blinking fast, there has been an error. Check the SD card!

sensorName_prep.h1: LET'S GIVE YOUR SENSOR AN IDENTITY
sensorName_prep.h4: This will help us know where this data is coming from...

sensorName.h2: What shall we name the sensor?
sensorName.h4: You can name it pretty much anything. This is how it will appear on the Smart Citizen map

location_prep.h2: Where will you install the sensor?
location_prep.h4: By pressing 'allow' on the pop up we can determine the current location of the sensor. You can manually adjust this later to anywhere you want to place the sensor

location_map.h2: If you want to adjust it or place it elsewhere, you can do that here
location_map.h4: Remember wherever your device goes, it will need Wi-Fi. Otherwise you'll have to use the SD card option

location_tags.h2: Is there anything we should know about the location?
location_tags.h4: Selecting from the tags below can help us make sense of the data, and compare it more accurately

confirm_location.h4: Finally, let's save all this work we've done

account1.h2: We can save the Kit with your email address
account1.h4: If you already have an account, we'll add it to that. If not, we'll quickly make a new one

login.h2b: enter your password below to finish.
login.h4: This will push all of your new Kit's data to your account

account2.h2: Nice, so you're new to Smart Citizen?
account2.h4: Add a username to your profile, so users know who owns the sensor

account3.h2: Now, choose a password to secure everything
account3.h4a: the password has to be at least 8 characters long
account3.h4b: And one more time to make sure there are no mistakes
account3.input1_error: The password must be at least 8 characters long

final.h2: You have successfully installed and connected the Smart Citizen Kit to the internet, and then added the kit to the global community of sensors!
final.h4: Visit SmartCitizen.me to see your Kit in action capturing data. Don't forget to read the manual for assembly instructions and tips on placing your sensor in the wild

confirm_parts.h4: Now let's put it all together

kitbuild6.h2: And finally, turn on the Kit
kitbuild6.text: Push the button on the Kit multiple times, until the LED is red
